journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Adaptive control of a legged capsular microrobot based on Lyapunov stability criteria

article-meta.aff: 1New Technology Research Center, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
2Mechanical Engineering Department, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
3Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Waterloo, ON, Canada

author-notes.corresp: *New Technology Research Center, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, P.O. Box 15194, Iran. email: rezanadafi@gmail.com

abstract.p: In this article, in order to develop endoscopic capsular, a capsular microrobot was designed with polymeric legs. The locomotion of the microrobot is modelled by considering surface forces and the microactuator model. The microrobot is controlled with an adaptive control algorithm. We exerted surface forces containing sliding friction and surface adhesion. Polymeric microactuator is an ionic polymer metal composite. The time-variant response of the polymeric microactuator is modelled based on a set of coupled electromechanical equations and an electric equivalent bulk of polymeric gel. The model reference adaptive control was constituted for precise position control of the microrobot. For the uncertainty parameter, the simulation of the microrobot’s dynamical model was obtained.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and integrated chip technology create a field of technology that has huge applications. Microrobotics is a category of MEMS and has applications in nuclear and military industries, medicine, etc. For more than two decades, researchers have been proposing and developing methods for providing propulsion at the tip of the endoscope, so that it can pull itself through the gastrointestinal tract. Most of these methods simulate the way animals – such as earthworm [1–11] and fish move [12].
Legged capsular microrobots are the focus of many MEMS research studies. Up to now, it has been understood that the capsular microrobot is the best to pass a tubular path [1–12].

In reference [3], the concept and preliminary modelling of a legged microrobot, locomotion in a tubular, compliant, and slippery environment is presented. After introducing and discussing the issue of autonomous locomotion of endoscopic devices, with reference to worldwide ongoing research in this field, the legged solution was proposed and peculiarities of this approach were described. The main disadvantage in the microrobotic field is, applying a micromotor as a propellant mechanism [3].

According to Ferreira and Fontaine [7], the operating driving principle, based on active frictional contact forces, offer direct-drive and low-speed characteristics at the microscale. A drawback of the study made by Ferreira and Fontaine [7] is the complexity of dynamic modelling and control to cope with the optimization of the intermittent friction drive mechanism. In reference [8], the locomotive mechanism is proposed for wireless capsule-type endoscopes. A prototype endoscope with four pairs of shape memory alloy (SMA), springs, and four clampers, was developed. The important impediment of SMA mechanism is higher than the IPMC, in energy consumption and high heat production.

The authors of reference [9] developed artificial earthworms by mimicking the structures and locomotion principles of real ones. Each prototype has four modules which can be driven independently according to defined undulatory patterns with a typical frequency of 0.5 Hz. Each module is actuated by one or more SMA springs whose configuration has been designed in order to limit the wiring problems and optimize working frequency. It is worth to note that heat and consuming energy are the main disadvantages of SMA devices. The robots are covered by a shaped silicone material which can beused as a platform to insert tiny legs to obtain the differential friction conditions. In order to approximate the behaviour of biological earthworms, the maximum speeds that the earthworm prototypes can reach are 0.22 mm/s without legs and 2.5 mm/s with legs.

The capsule-type microrobot proposed in ‘Paddling Based Microrobot for Capsule Endoscopes’ [10], has synchronized multiple legs that are actuated by a linear actuator and two mobile cylinders inside the capsule. By the novel kinematic relation between the legs and the mobile cylinders, the microrobot can easily move forward in the gastro-intestine. The proposed locomotive mechanism is not only easy to be used for microcapsule endoscopes, but also effective to move inside the intestinal tract.

In reference [11], an innovative worm-like robot controlled by cellular neural networks is proposed and made of an ionic polymer–metal composite. Worm-like locomotion is performed by bending the actuators sequentially from ‘tail’ to ‘head’, imitating the travelling wave, observed in real-world undulatory locomotion. As a disadvantage, this worm-like robot has no robotic structure.
For the legged capsular microrobot which was first mentioned, the mathematical modelling with adhesion force and sliding friction, IPMC modelling, and adaptive control was implemented.

sec.title: 2 MOTION MECHANISM OF THE MICROROBOT
sec.p:
This propounded microrobot which is presented in reference [1] has active and passive parts. The cylindrical active part of the microrobot has length 15 mm and diameter 4 mm (Fig. 1). Fig. 1
The active part of microrobot

The active part produces the driving force. The cylindrical passive part with length 15 mm and diameter 8 mm carries the equipment. The active part has eight symmetric legs (Fig. 2). Fig. 2
The active part comprising the middle plates and the legs in addition to the passive part

The legs connect to the body by rigid middle plates. The rigid middle plates are in polymeric channels. These channels are filled with a certain polymer, which is sprung for middle plate motion. The planar motion of the microrobot comes from the polymeric legs. Figure 3 shows how the capsular microrobot moves forward. Fig. 3
The walking principle and the sequence of the ciliary motion-based eight-legged walking device

As shown in Fig. 3, the four legs of number 1 are actuated in step (2). Each leg is considered to be an IPMC microoperator; therefore, by actuation, it is meant that each IPMC microoperator is exposed in an electric field resulting in the deformation of that leg. In this step, the pressure of the legs causes vertical motion in the middle plates. This motion of the middle plates moves the central mass of the microrobot forward horizontally. Then, in step (3), the four legs of number 2 are actuated. Next in step (4), the first group of legs (leg no. 1), and then in step (5), the second group of legs (leg no. 2) will be relaxed. Thus, in steps (4) and (5), by means of the spring polymer between the middle plates, the microrobot’s centre of mass moves forward again.

sec.title: 3.1 Surface adhesion
sec.p:
A method to use adhesion force to lift objects was first introduced by Rollot [5]. Surface adhesion contains capillary, Fc, electrostatic, Fe and Vander Waals, Fvdw forces [15–22]. Figure 4. shows the contrast of these forces for tow-contacted surfaces. Fig. 4
The surface adhesion component [15]
Therefore, FAdh is defined as equation (3.1) [16]. As shown in Fig. 4, FAdh is exerted between the legs and the wall. (3.1)

sec.title: 3.2 Capillary force
sec.p: Capillary forces, Fc, are manifestations of the surface tension of trapped capillary liquids. These liquids exert a force due to the Laplace pressure difference between outside and inside of the abutting liquids. Capillary forces are given by equation (3.2) for the semispherical plate [15, 16]. (3.2) where γl, D, Rball, and d are, respectively, the surface tension, the separation distance, the sphere radius, and the height of immersion.

sec.title: 3.3 Electrostatic force
sec.p: Electrostatic forces, Fe, can arise due to: (a) an externally applied voltage across the interface, (b) the difference in material work functions of the surfaces, and (c) an electrostatic charging resulting from the release. However, in this field of research, due to the microrobot’s legs being fixed, the electrostatic force is considered to be zero.

sec.title: 3.4 Van der Waals force
sec.p: Van der Waals force is calculated based on the interaction between individual atoms making up the particles. The non-retarded energy of the interaction between particles 1 and 2, separated by a distance H, of volumes V1 and V2 containing q1 and q2 atoms/cm3 is defined by equation (3.3) [17]. (3.3) where λij is London’s constant, whose value depends on the atomic numbers of the two interacting atoms.

The Van der Waals force will be given by the variation energy (equation (3.3)) directed to the atomic distance. Equation (3.4) has been solved for the Van der Waals force equations between spherical and plated surfaces [18]. Finally, the surface adhesion is determined by equation (3.5). L is the external load and μe is calculated by equation (3.6). S is the shear strength of contacting plates and Pe has been introduced in references [21, 22]. (3.4) (3.5) (3.6)
where A is called Hamaker’s coefficient (or constant), R the radius of sphere, and Ff the stick friction.

sec.title: 4 MODELLING THE IPMC
sec.p: IPMCs have been considered for various applications due to their lightweight, large bending, and low actuation voltage requirements [23]. IPMC is an electroactive polymer that bends in response to electric stimuli. In this article, when input voltage is applied to it, cation ion which moves freely in the membrane is drawn to the electrode by the electric field with water molecules. Then, one side of the electrode is dilated, and another shrunk, as a result of which the IPMC membrane bends [14,23, 24].

Kim [24] has introduced the mathematical IPMC model for the direct task. The relation between voltage (input) and torque (output) is expressed as (4.1) where LI, σp, h, KI, and VA are cross-coefficient, electric conductance, IPMC thickness, permeability, and applied step voltage of the IPMC, respectively. R1, R2, and C are the resistance values for each RC circuit, the inter-plate resistance value, and the capacitance value, respectively.

sec.title: 5 MODELLING THE MICROBOT MOTION
sec.p:
The dynamical model of the microrobot is determined on the basis of surface forces model, polymeric actuator model, and proposed structure of the microrobot. Figure 5 shows the free body diagram for each leg and its middle plate (the one-quarter model of the microrobot). In this figure, θ is the angle of the leg installation to the perpendicular direction, Rx the sliding friction of the passive part as load, F the reaction of the wall, and T and Ky the IPMC torque and spring force, respectively. Fig. 5
Free body diagram for the leg and the middle plate
Equation (5.1) can be written for the ‘Base point’ of Fig. 5. The second law of Newton has been written to achieve the torques around the base point which is as shown in equation (5.1) (5.1)

Also, with the angular acceleration, equation (5.1) can be written as equation (5.2) (5.2) where i is the inertia moment, L the leg length, Ky the spring stiffness, T the IPMC torque, and x the amount of motion. Rx, the sliding friction, is defined on the basis of the Stribeck friction [25] according to equation (5.7) and α the angular momentum of the IPMC beam. Since L is the length of the beam, therefore, a relation can be seen between the angular momentum and the linear acceleration, which is (5.3) where in equation (5.3), x is the linear acceleration. In fact, when the microrobot’s leg (IPMC beam) sticks to the wall because of surface and frictional forces, and there is a no slipping condition, as a result the head of the IPMC attached to the body of the microrobot will actuate. Actually, the angular momentum of the IPMC beam and the linear acceleration of the microrobot become constrained cinematically which has been shown in equation (5.3).
Therefore, from equations (5.2) and (5.3), it can be concluded that (5.4)
In equation (5.4), I is the inertia moment per length of the IPMC beam. By simplifying equations (5.1) to (5.4), it can be seen that (5.5)
The first term in right side of equation (5.5), T is the torque applied from the IPMC which has been calculated in equation (5.6) as shown in the following equation [13] (5.6)

In the above equation, Γ is the torque per IPMC width, w and h width and depth of IPMC beam, respectively, LI, KI, and σP are cross-coefficient, permeability, and the Poisson ratio. R1, R2 and C are resistance and capacitance specifications of IPMC. VA and t are input voltage and time, respectively.
The second term in equation (5.5), 14LRxcosθ is the torque of the surface force which can be achieved by multiplying Rx in the effective arm relative to the base point, L cos θ.
The amount of the surface force, Rx, is computed in equation (5.7), and since Fig. 5 is a one quarter model of the microrobot, thus it must compute one quarter of the whole amount of Rx.
In equation (5.7), FC is the Coulomb friction level, FS the level of the stiction force, Fv the viscous friction level, and νc the Stribeck velocity.

The third term of equation (5.5), x L Ky sin θ tan θ is the torque resulted from the spring force existing in the active module of the microrobot, which according to Fig. 5, is exactly under the middle plate.
The amount of this force is Kyx tan θ, which by multiplying it in Lsinθ, the effective arm, the torque resulted from the spring force will be achieved.

sec.title: 6 ADAPTIVE CONTROL SYSTEM
sec.p:
In this microrobot, the sliding friction parameters in movement and surrounding alternations are changed. Because of the mentioned change, dynamical actions and the centre of mass’s motion control must be improved. To achieve this, we could use the model reference adaptive control (MRAC). In the MRAC system, the structure is defined but parameters and coefficients are unknown or changing. In fact, the poles and zeros are known but their exact places are not. Figure 6 exposes the adaptive controller of MRAC. Fig. 6
Representing different parts of the MRAC adaptive control [26]

sec.title: 6.1 Designing the adaptive control system with uncertainty parameters
sec.p: For eliminating non-linear parts and controlling, the feedback linearization is used. Initially, the system dynamic model, equation (5.5), can be rewritten as shown below (6.1) where m is the mass of the microrobot, T input torque, L length of each leg, Ky spring constant of the middle polymeric spring, x the movement of the centre of mass, and θ the angle of leg installation to the perpendicular direction.
The dynamic model of the system is non-linear but the input signal linearization, T, is according to equation (6.2) in which Ur is the reference input. (6.2a) (6.2b)

The parameters of mass, length of the legs, and the installation angle of the legs are assumed constant and friction parameters Fc, Fs, and Fv, are uncertain. The uncertainty of the dynamic model of the microrobot shown in equation (6.2) would act in the form of equation (6.3). (6.3)

Thus, the adaption law for this controller will be as followed:According to the adaption law, p·=-Γsw, equation (6.6), and the Lyapunov function presented, the designed adaptive control system provides a perfect tracking with asymptotical parameter convergence.

sec.p:
To study the behaviour of the adaptive control system, a mathematical simulation of the microrobot’s adaptive control was performed. The numerical properties in Tables 1 to 4 were utilized in the simulation. Table 1

sec.title: 7 SIMULATING THE CLOSED-LOOP BEHAVIOUR OF THE DYNAMIC MODEL OF THE MICROROBOT WITH UNCERTAINTY PARAMETERS
sec.p:
In this section, the dynamic model is simulated with assuming uncertain parameters. In simulations of the dynamic model with uncertainty parameters, the amount of the controller coefficient is assumed λ = 200, the coefficient of adaptation law is assumed as
and also it is assumed that a1 = Fc, a2 = Fs - Fc and a3 = Fv. The reference signal input to adaptive control system is sinusoidal with amplitude of 0.001 m. In this section, the parameters are unknown and constant. Figs 7 to 12 are deduced with using the numerical amounts of Tables 1 to 4. Fig. 7
Tracking error with sinusoidal path and uncertainty parameters

Figure 6 indicated that with sinusoidal reference input (Xd), the adaptive controller will converge to the reference very well. Figures 8 and 9 expose the amount of consumption voltage and torque for perfect tracking. After convergence, the amount of the required torque reached a constant amount of 0.5 × 10-6 N m and voltage became under 1 V. This torque quantity is easily available by an IPMC actuator in this size. Figures 10 to 12 show the behaviour of the estimated parameters. The range of the real amount of parameters a1 and a2 is near 10−4 and the estimated amounts also converge to this number. However, the real quantity of parameter a3 is 0.02, while the estimated amount converges to 0.015. Fig. 8
The required voltage for the microrobot’s adaptive control Fig. 9
The required torque for the microrobot’s adaptive control Fig. 10
Parameter a1 resulted from the microrobot’s adaptive control Fig. 11
Parameter a2 resulted from the microrobot’s adaptive control Fig. 12
The parameter a3 resulted from the microrobot’s adaptive control

Next, the behaviour of adaptive control system is studied with sinusoidal reference input (Xd) and sinusoidal variation of the parameters. The amplitudes of the sinusoidal variation of parameters a1 is 1 × 10-4, a2 0.5 × 10-4, and a3 0.02. The frequency of the sinusoidal changing is 0.2 Hz. These alternations will be added to the initial amount of parameters. Comparisons between real amounts and estimated amounts with the adaptive system are shown in Figs13 to 16. Fig. 13
The required torque for the microrobot’s control acting on the sinusoidal path and sinusoidal changes for parameters Fig. 14
Parameter a1 resulted from controlling the microrobot with the applied sinusoidal path and sinusoidal changes for the parameters Fig. 15
Parameter a2 resulted from controlling the microrobot with the applied sinusoidal path and sinusoidal changes for the parameters Fig. 16
Parameter a3 resulted from controlling the microrobot with the applied sinusoidal path and sinusoidal changes for parameters

Finally, it is assumed that the parameters are unavailable. The varying shocks of parameters are between 2 to 4 s. The varying amplitudes for a1 is 10-4, a2 1.3 × 10-4, and for a3 0.02. These alternations will be added to the initial amount of parameters. Comparison between real and estimated amounts with the adaptive system are shown in Figs17 to 21. Fig. 17
The tracking error of the microrobot with the application of disturbance to the parameters

Figure 17 depicts that the tracking error first starts from zero, then is disturbed between 2 to 4 s, and afterwards will be zero again. However, the adaptive system did not approach instability. Figure 18 shows the consumption torque with the application of disturbance is an IPMC authorized ability. Figures 19 to 21 show that the behaviour of the estimated parameters is affected by shocking changes, and after the alternations, they will converge to a constant amount. Fig. 18
The required torque for controlling the microrobot with the application of disturbance to the parameters Fig. 19
Parameter a1 resulted from controlling the microrobot with the application of disturbance to the parameters Fig. 20
Parameter a2 resulted from controlling the microrobot with the application of disturbance to the parameters Fig. 21
Parameter a3 resulted from controlling the microrobot with the application of disturbance to the parameters

sec.title: 8 RESULT ANALYSIS
sec.p:
For the microrobot model, the maximum required torque was measured based on mass, angle of leg installation, stiffness of middle plates, and simulations results. Figures 22 to 24 were drawn in Microsoft Excel software to demonstrate the effects of change in the amounts of mass, angle of IPMC leg installation, and the stiffness of middle plates to the maximum required torque. Fig. 22
Demonstrating mass increase to maximum required toque Fig. 23
Demonstrating the increase in the angle of IPMC leg installation to the maximum required toque Fig. 24
Demonstrating the increase in the stiffness of middle plates to the maximum required torque

Figure 22 shows that if the mass of the microrobot is more than 5 g, then the required torque would be more than IPMC actuator capacity; so, the microrobot would not have any motion and therefore is fixed in its place.

Figure 23 exposes that with the approach of the leginstallation angle to 90°, the amount of the generated torque by IPMC to obtain the controlling torque would increase and in 90°, the generated torque approaches infinity (∞. )To attain the maximum movement for the microrobot with the best amount of generated torque, 60° is selected for our simulations.

Figure 24 shows that with increasing the stiffness of the middle plate IPMC should generate to a greater torque. However, since the stiffness constant is more than 0.22 N/m, the required torque would be more than IPMC actuator capacity. This results the microrobot being fixed and having no motion.

Studying Figures 25 to 30 shows.
The generated torque has a linear relation to the input voltage of IPMC, 1/R2, and LI and an exponential relation to R1. Thus, the increase of any of these parameters will boost the generated torque area.
The response and settling times are linearly related to 1/R1 and 1/C. Therefore, by increasing these parameters, IPMC reaches to a permanent state more quickly. C and R2 are ineffectual on generated torque and settling time of IPMC, respectively.
In the fabrication and moulding steps of IPMC, attempts should be put through, gaining the maximum amount of LI, C, and R2 and an optimized amount of R1, so that the IPMC microactuator will have maximum generated torque area and minimum settling time. The quantity of the generated torque of common IPMCs is 0.016 N m/g (IPMC business Sale Company ERI website [27] which sells IPMC online). This amount is presumed to be the actuator’s saturated limit.
Results in Section 9 indicate that the adaptive system of the microrobot has a good robustness to parameter changing in a range less than six times of the initial amounts. In this condition, the required torque is less than 1.5 × 10-6 N m, which is in the common range of the IPMCs in the market. The adaptive system will be affected while applying the disturbance to the parameters without instability.
Fig. 25
Effects of increasing the input voltage on the amount of generated torque of IPMC Fig. 26
Effects of increasing the inverse amount of R2 on the amount of generated torque of IPMC Fig. 27
Effects of increasing LI on the amount of generated torque of IPMC Fig. 28
Effects of increasing R1 on the amount of the generated torque of IPMC Fig. 29
Effects of increasing R1 on the amount of settling time Fig. 30
Effects of increasing 1/C on the amount of settling time

sec.title: 9 CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sec.p: In this article, an eight-legged capsular microrobot with passive and active modules was evaluated. Ifthe total mass of the microrobot, the stiffness polymer, and the installation angle exceed 5 g, 0.22 N/m, and 70°, respectively, then the actuators are saturated.

Result simulation of dynamical model microrobot shows that the best installation angle of legs is 60°; proper mass of microrobot is 2 g, and speed marching is 1 mm/s. By applying these elements, a very satisfying robustness and stability will be achieved.

A half-made model prototype of this microrobot was designed, which can be seen in Fig. 31. In field tests, the prototype walked with an open-loop mechanism in elective paths. Fig. 31
The half-made prototype of this microrobot

In future work, the complete microrobot system with adaptive controller will be designed and fabricated. Therefore, operation of this adaptive control system will be examined to changes in parameters, as mass and stiffness practically.
